column1: So recently me and a few work buddies had an altercation with our friend about whether two male friends should text/call each other every day. It’s not that we literally need a daily phone call; it’s that outside of work he never reaches out
column3: and treats any effort to connect after hours like a nuisance. We spend a lot of time talking at work
column5: but that’s because we’re scheduled in the same place. Friendship isn’t just convenience—it’s choosing each other when you don’t have to.

column1: We tried offering compromises: a weekly check-in
column4: even a quick “you good?” sometimes. He shut it down with “I’m not a texter” and called our expectations childish and “relationship standards
column5: ” which felt dismissive and weirdly gendered. We’re not asking for heart-to-hearts every night; we’re asking for basic reciprocity so it doesn’t feel one-sided.

column1: He benefits from the social vibe at work but won’t put in any intentional effort afterward
column2: then mocks us for wanting some. That’s why we’re upset—and why he’s at fault here. He doesn’t have to text daily
column3: but refusing any middle ground and belittling our needs is on him.
